message: Week 5 Learning Outcomes identified: (1) Memory definitions and processes, (2) Multi-Store Model (MSM), (3) Episodic/Semantic/Procedural memory types, (4) Working Memory Model (WMM), (5) Levels of Processing Model (LOP), (6) Theories of Forgetting. Week 6: Perception - Gestalt principles, depth perception, perceptual constancy, illusions, ecological vs constructivist theories.

MEMORY KEY CONCEPTS (20+ items): (1) Three memory processes: encoding/storage/retrieval, (2) Three encoding types: acoustic/visual/semantic, (3) STM capacity 7±2 (Miller 1956), (4) STM duration 15-30 sec (Peterson 1959), (5) Chunking increases STM, (6) LTM unlimited capacity/duration, (7) Multi-Store Model (Atkinson & Shiffrin 1968), (8) Serial Position Effect: primacy/recency, (9) HM case: anterograde amnesia, (10) Episodic memory: autobiographical events, (11) Semantic memory: general knowledge, (12) Procedural memory: skills/habits, (13) Working Memory Model: central executive/phonological loop/visuo-spatial/episodic buffer, (14) Levels of Processing: deep semantic > shallow (Craik & Lockhart 1972), (15) Craik & Tulving 1975: semantic processing best recall, (16) Decay theory: fading over time, (17) Displacement theory: new pushes out old in STM, (18) Proactive interference: old blocks new, (19) Retroactive interference: new blocks old, (20) Efficient forgetting essential (Schacter 2002)

PERCEPTION KEY CONCEPTS (18+ items): (1) Perception: organization/interpretation of sensory info, (2) Distal vs proximal stimulus, (3) Gestalt: whole > sum of parts, (4) Figure-ground separation, (5) Proximity law: close elements grouped, (6) Closure law: fill gaps, (7) Similarity law: similar parts together, (8) Continuity law: follow continuous patterns, (9) Symmetry law: symmetrical elements unified, (10) Retinal disparity (binocular): eye separation creates depth, (11) Convergence (binocular): eye rotation for nearby focus, (12) Relative size/interposition/linear perspective/texture gradient/light-shadow/aerial perspective/relative height (7 monocular cues), (13) Size constancy: object size perceived constant, (14) Ames Room illusion, (15) Shape/brightness/colour/location constancy, (16) Five illusions: Ponzo/Horizontal-Vertical/Muller-Lyer/Poggendorf/Titchener's circles, (17) Gregory's Constructivist (top-down): brain constructs using prior knowledge, (18) Gibson's Ecological (bottom-up): direct perception via affordances, (19) Harris 1998: theories complementary for different tasks

Important examples for quiz generation identified: MEMORY - (a) Chunking: hyphenated phone numbers, (b) Shopping list MSM vs WMM comparison, (c) HM case study for anterograde amnesia, (d) Flashbulb memories: celebrity deaths, (e) Procedural: riding bicycle/brushing teeth, (f) Proactive interference: old phone blocking new, (g) Retroactive: new language affecting old, (h) LOP "elephant" example. PERCEPTION - (a) Melody vs individual notes (Gestalt), (b) Forest navigation (Gibson direct), (c) Messy handwriting (Gregory constructivist), (d) Ames Room size illusion, (e) Door shape from angles, (f) White shirt brightness in different light, (g) Red apple color in different lighting. These examples provide clear, unambiguous scenarios for quiz questions.

Week 5-6 structure recommendation: Content naturally splits into TWO major topics - (A) MEMORY and (B) PERCEPTION. Both are substantial enough to be separate weeks OR can be combined as Week 5 Part 1 (Memory) and Week 5 Part 2/Week 6 (Perception). Memory has 3 major models (MSM, WMM, LOP) with 20+ concepts. Perception has 3 theoretical approaches (Gestalt, Constructivist, Ecological) with 19+ concepts. Suggest checking actual course schedule (syllabus or week folders) to determine if these are Week 5 only OR Weeks 5-6 split. Both topics have sufficient depth for comprehensive quiz generation (30+ potential questions each).
